metadata.title: Broad-Spectrum Tunable Photoluminescent Nanomaterials Constructed from a Modular Light-Harvesting Platform Based on Macrocyclic Amphiphiles

sections.text:

sections.heading: Constructed from a Modular Light-Harvesting Platform
Based on Macrocyclic Amphiphiles
sections.text:
Zhe Xu, Shu Peng, Yu-Ying Wang, Ji-Kai Zhang, Alexandra I. Lazar, and Dong-Sheng Guo*
Z. Xu, S. Peng, Y.-Y. Wang, J.-K. Zhang, Prof. D.-S. Guo Department of Chemistry State Key Laboratory of Elemento-Organic Chemistry Nankai University Tianjin 300071, China E-mail: dshguo@nankai.edu.cn A. I. Lazar Department of Life Sciences and Chemistry Jacobs University Bremen Campus Ring 1, D-28759 Bremen, Germany Prof. D.-S. Guo Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering Nankai University Tianjin 300071, China
DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
transfer.[11] On the other hand, the donor/acceptor ratios are expected to be conveniently varied to achieve tunable broad spectrum of energy transfer outputs.[8a,b,12]
In this regard, macrocyclic amphiphiles, deemed as “surfactants with host–guest recognition sites,”[13] attract our particular attention, giving the following advantages.[14] For one, macrocyclic amphiphiles can conveniently assemble into structurally well-defined supramolecular aggregates that can noncovalently incorporate donor/acceptor pairs without any additional synthetic effort as long as compatibility permits, and macro cyclic amphiphiles enable even more precise control of the spatial distribution of the luminophores at discrete, isolated sites, i.e., outer cavity encapsulation and inner hydrophobic entrapment. For another, macrocyclic encapsulation has recently emerged as an elegant solution for self-quenching of luminophores,[15]
Development of broad-spectrum tunable photoluminescent nanomaterials is receiving much research attention because of their promise for applications in light-emitting devices,[1] optical sensors,[2] as well as fluorescent inks for security printing.[3] Toward this goal, light-harvesting systems involving energy migration can be exploited for the generation of multiple fluorescent emissions by tuning the energy-transfer efficiency between donor–acceptor components.[3b,4] Inspired by nature, scientists have demonstrated a diverse array of artificial lightharvesting systems based on various scaffolds, including dendrimers,[5] micelles/ vesicles,[6] gels,[7] (bio)-polymer assemblies,[8] host–guest ensembles,[9] and organic–inorganic hybrid materials.[10] However, many current approaches require covalent integration of either the donor or the acceptor, or even both, not only limiting the synthetic accessibility but also hampering easy access to large libraries of light-harvesting entities and their high-throughput testing. Consequently, rational design of novel modular light-harvesting platforms directed by selfassembly is highly appealing for making smart broad-spectrum tunable photoluminescent nanomaterials. On one hand, a structural matrix is required that furnishes both spatial organization and specific binding environments for the donor/acceptor luminophores, which ensures efficient energy
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of operating principle of the light-harvesting platform based on AmCnAs.
2 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
C o
m m
u n
iC a ti
o n
which remains a grand challenge to achieve high local densities of luminophores without causing detrimental self-quenching.[16]
Herein, we report the de novo design of a modular lightharvesting platform (Scheme 1) from calixarene amphiphiles, a typical class of macrocyclic amphiphiles, where the noncovalent positioning of donors and acceptors can be discretely addressed, in this case, reliant on self-sorting encapsulation and entrapment, respectively. Thanks to the dynamic nature of noncovalent encapsulation and entrapment, we achieved a broad-spectrum of energy transfer outputs, notably including white-light emission, based on the delicate adjustment of the molar ratio between donor and acceptor. Moreover, the encapsulation of donors into calixarene cavities, or the compartmentalization effect, successfully overcomes the daunting yet long-unresolved selfquenching. On account of these combined attributes, we further explored the application of such a tunable broad-spectrum system as fluorescent inks. In the solid state, the fluorescence did not disappear with evaporation of the solvent (no aggregation-caused quenching effect) and the assemblies retained its stimuli-responsive character that emitting different luminescent colors upon changing the concentrations of components.
Amphiphilic calix[n]arenes (AmCnAs, n = 4 and 5) were prepared by decorating hydrophilic choline groups at the upper rim and hydrophobic alkyl chains at the lower rim (see the Supporting Information), displaying unique superiority in self-assembly and host–guest recognition. Prior to energy transfer studies, the assembly property of AmCnAs was evaluated. AmC4A and AmC5A have similar critical aggregation concentrations of 5.2 × 10−6 and 5.5 × 10−6 m, respectively (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements
reveal that both AmC4A and AmC5A form large-sized aggregates with averaged diameters of 149 and 79 nm, respectively (Figure 1a and Figure S7, Supporting Information). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron micro scopy images of AmC5A show the spherical-like morphology with comparable size to DLS results (Figure 1b and Figure S6, Supporting Information). The aggregation diameter is much larger than the molecular size of AmCnAs, which indicates the vesicular aggregation rather than the micellar aggregation. The vesicular aggregation of AmC5A was further validated by small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), giving the wall thickness of 5.1 nm, in good accordance with doubled length of AmC5A (Figure 1c,d). It should be mentioned that the size of the amphiphilic assembly of AmC4A increased to 602 nm upon addition of 1-anilino-8-naphthalenesulfonate (1,8-ANS, the screened donor hereinafter), while that of AmC5A remains constant upon encapsulation of 1,8-ANS (averaged diameter of 80 nm, Figure S7, Supporting Information). Moreover, the AmC5A assembly is stable enough to achieve a shelf life of several weeks without agglomeration and precipitation, but not AmC4A. One possibility is that the more symmetric AmC4A has a higher tendency to crystallize and precipitate. Also noting that nile red (NiR), a hydrophobic dye, presents stronger fluorescence upon entrapping in the assemblies of AmC5A than AmC4A (Figure S8, Supporting Information), indicating the more hydrophobic subphase originating from the more compact aggregation of AmC5A. All these phenomena indicate that AmC5A forms more robust amphiphilic assemblies for serving as the light-harvesting platform than AmC4A.
To fabricate a highly efficient light-harvesting system based on the present calixarene amphiphile platform, 1,8-ANS and
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
Figure 1. a) DLS data, b) TEM image, and c) SAXS scan of the AmC5A vesicle in water (pH = 7.0, [AmC5A] = 100 × 10−6 m). d) Energy-minimized molecular structure of AmC5A.
3wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
C o m m u n iC a tio n
4,7-bis(thien-2-yl)-2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (DBT, a hydrophobic dye showing superior emission in hydrophobic milieu) were employed as the donor/acceptor pair on account of the discrete addressability, spectrum overlap, and broad-spectrum tunability. The spatial distribution of the luminophores could be addressed in a self-sorting manner, that is, encapsulation of the 1,8-ANS donor into the calixarene cavity and entrapment of the DBT acceptor into the hydrophobic bilayer. The absorption of DBT overlaps well with the emission of 1,8-ANS (Figure 2a), which promises substantial energy transfer. More importantly, the emission of 1,8-ANS is blue and the emission of DBT is orange, which offers an opportunity to achieve broad-spectrum outputs conveniently.
Screening of donor candidates identifies 1,8-ANS, whose fluorescence was dramatically enhanced by the complexation of AmCnAs (Figure 2b), as the ideal antenna molecule for the following energy transfer studies (see the Supporting Information). A quantitative evaluation shows that both AmC4A and AmC5A bind 1,8-ANS strongly with association constants of
2.3 × 106 and 3.2 × 106 m−1, respectively (Figure S11, Supporting Information). The fluorescence intensity enhancement upon complexation, Ibound/Ifree, is calculated to be to 195- and 155- fold for AmC4A and AmC5A, respectively. We presumed that it was the deep inclusion of 1,8-ANS into the extended cavity of AmCnAs that restricted the intramolecular rotation of the dye, leading to the enhancement of emission intensity.[17] The simulation results of the host–guest complexation structure further validated our assumption, where 1,8-ANS fits well within the extended cavity of AmCnAs (Figure 2c and Figure S14, Supporting Information). The quantum yield of 1,8-ANS bound to AmC5A is up to 10.2%, increasing drastically from that of free 1,8-ANS (φ = 0.3%, see the Supporting Information).
Titration of DBT gradually lowered the donor emission at 475 nm while enhancing that of the acceptor at 575 nm when the donor was selectively excited at 369 nm (Figure 2e). In the absence of 1,8-ANS, irradiation of DBT at 369 nm yielded negligible emission since DBT has negligible absorption at
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
Figure 2. a) Normalized emission spectrum of AmC5A/1,8-ANS and absorption spectrum of AmC5A/DBT. b) Fluorescence spectra (λex = 354 nm) of 1,8-ANS (1 × 10−6 m) in the absence and presence of AmC4A (1 × 10−6 m) or AmC5A (1 × 10−6 m) in water (pH = 7.0). c) Molecular simulation of AmC4A/1,8-ANS, where the long alkyl chains of AmC4A were omitted for clarity. d) Absorption spectra of AmC5A/1,8-ANS in water (pH = 7.0) with different concentrations of DBT, [1,8-ANS] = [AmC5A] = 20 × 10−6 m. Fluorescence spectra of AmC5A/1,8-ANS in water (pH = 7.0) e) and in PBS buffer (10 × 10−3 m, pH = 7.0) f) with different concentrations of DBT, λex = 369 nm, [1,8-ANS] = [AmC5A] = 20 × 10−6 m.
4 wileyonlinelibrary.com © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
C o
m m
u n
iC a ti
o n this wavelength (Figure S15, Supporting Information), which
ruled out the possibility for direct excitation of the acceptor on excitation of the donor. Moreover, the 1,8-ANS absorption, at 360–390 nm, stayed nearly constant while that of DBT, at 280– 350 and 400–550 nm, increased gradually upon addition of DBT (Figure 2d), which is an indication of the absence of any groundstate interactions between donor and acceptor molecules. These results indicated Förster resonance energy transfer from 1,8- ANS to DBT. Additional evidence for the energy transfer was obtained from the excitation spectrum of AmC5A/DBT in presence or absence of 1,8-ANS (Figure S16, Supporting Information). The intensity at 350–370 nm increased drastically with the addition of 1,8-ANS.
The energy-transfer efficiency (ΦET) was calculated as 85% when mixing 1,8-ANS and DBT at a molar ratio of 10:1. As can be seen, the majority of the 1,8-ANS fluorescence was quenched by only a small fraction of DBT. If we assume n1,8-ANS fluorophores could be quenched by one DBT, we could treat (1,8- ANS)n as one unit and model the quenching by a 1:1 binding isotherm.[6b,c] The concentration of (1,8-ANS)n was obtained as (3.3 ± 0.4) × 10−7 m, and the number of 1,8-ANS chromophores in the light-harvesting unit was calculated to be n = 61 ± 7 (see the Supporting Information). That is, one DBT acceptor is capable of quenching 61 1,8-ANS donors in our system. Consequently, the DBT emission by energy transfer from multiple 1,8-ANS surpasses that by its own excitation owing to the antenna effect. We obtained the antenna effect as 4.5 (1,8-ANS/DBT, 20 × 10−6/0.4 × 10−6 m), displaying definitely the light-harvesting outcome.
The high degree of spatial organization of the donor/acceptor luminophores with well-defined relative orientations and distances
is crucial to achieve high energy-transfer efficiency.[8a,b,12,18] It is therefore acceptable that the performance of amphiphilic assembly, i.e., aggregating stability and compactness, would affect the energy-transfer efficiency, and thus the spectrum tunability. To further explore the compactness of amphiphilic assembly on energy transfer, we transferred the light-harvesting system from water to phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) buffer (10 × 10−3 m, pH = 7.0). It is well demonstrated that the amphiphilic assembly of ionic surfactants was boosted by increasing ionic strength because the charge repulsion between ionic heads was reduced when the electrical double layer surrounding the ionic heads was compressed.[19] Closer packing of the ionic heads leads to more compact aggregation. As expected, all energy-transfer parameters were expectedly refined in PBS buffer (Figure 2f): ΦET = 97% (1,8-ANS/DBT, 20 × 10−6/2.1 × 10−6 m), antenna effect = 6.6 (1,8-ANS/DBT, 20 × 10−6/0.4 × 10−6 m), and n = 105 ± 10.[20] The lifetime measurements further validated the energy transfer. AmC5A/1,8-ANS gives a fluorescence lifetime of 5.1 ns, which was drastically reduced to less than 1 ns upon addition of DBT (Figure S26, Supporting Information). It should be mentioned that even 1,8-ANS and DBT are susceptible to photobleaching individually, no appreciable photobleaching was observed for the present system upon excitation over 80 min (Figure S17, Supporting Information), probably benefiting from the improved photo stability by cavity encapsulation and bilayer entrapment.
Benefiting from the dynamic nature of noncovalent encapsulation and entrapment, we are capable of tuning the emission color conveniently by delicately adjusting the molar ratio between 1,8- ANS and DBT, thus achieving a broad-spectrum outputs relied on the energy-transfer efficiency. Figure 3a shows a map for the
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
5wileyonlinelibrary.com© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
C o m m u n iC a tio n
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
emission of AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT vesicles in PBS buffer with varying donor-to-acceptor ratios on a 2D projection of the CIE (Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage) xy chromaticity diagram; with increasing acceptor concentration, the color changes from blue to orange, and passes through pure white. The sample with donor-to-acceptor molar ratio 25:1 is perceived as pure white-light emission with color coordinates (0.31, 0.34), which are very close to the exact white point (0.33, 0.33). The color temperature at this point was noted as 6581 K. Moreover, the CIE diagram in water does not show spectrum as broad as in PBS buffer (Figure 3d), even with higher acceptor/donor ratios, resulting from the distinguishable amphiphilic aggregation. In PBS buffer, the more compact aggregation leads to the higher energy-transfer efficiency and acceptor emission, which are significant factors to realize tunable broad-spectrum outputs by inputting different donor/acceptor ratios.
The noncovalently discrete addressability of donor/acceptor components and tunable broad spectrum inspired us to explore the application of the modular light-harvesting platform as fluorescent inks. Upon writing the predefined solutions on ordinary white papers, the fluorescence of AmC5A/1,8-ANS was well kept in the solid state (Figure 4a), and the energy transfer process was not impeded since obvious changes of emission colors were observed by varying donor-to-acceptor ratios (Figure 4b,c and Figure S22, Supporting Information). As control experiments, there is no appreciable emission under irradiation at 365 nm when
writing with DBT only (Figure 4d), and also, no appreciable spectrum change was observed when writing with 1,8-ANS in the absence or presence of DBT (Figure 4e,f). The solid-state results further validated that the calixarene amphiphiles served as the prerequisite platform to achieve the spectrum tunability via energy transfer. Furthermore, we rewrote the AmC5A and AmC5A/DBT inks on the preexisting 1,8-ANS (Figure 4h), and observed dramatic spectrum changes from light blue (1,8-ANS) to dark blue (AmC5A/1,8-ANS) and to orange (AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT). The fluorescent inks based on AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT ensembles provide an extensive fluorescent color matrix by facilely tuning the concentrations of components. More importantly, the system’s outputs depend nonlinearly on the concentrations of components when taking the complex supramolecular equilibria into account, which points toward a proof-of-principle for encryption coding. Such a fascinating supramolecular encryption strategy was well demonstrated by Prof. Stoddart and co-workers very recently.[3c]
In summary, we have designed and demonstrated a modular light-harvesting platform built from calixarene amphiphiles in aqueous media, where the spatial arrangement of donors and acceptors is discretely addressable by cavity encapsulation and bilayer entrapment, respectively, two types of orthogonal noncovalent interactions. In addition to full suppression of
self-quenching by compartmentalization, this multicomponent self-assembly strategy does not require covalent integration of either donors or acceptors, lending it simplicity and versatility to constructing sophisticated light-harvesting systems with arbitrary compatible donor/acceptor pairs. Varying the molar ratio between 1,8-ANS and DBT allows for the fine-tuning of the energy transfer process, and thus, to our gratifying surprise, broad-spectrum outputs, suggesting promised application as fluorescent inks with capability of encryption coding. Most importantly, the reported strategy paves a new avenue for light-harvesting nanomaterials from macrocyclic amphiphiles featuring full modularity and facile integration.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.
Acknowledgements This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21322207), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central
Figure 4. The features of fluorescent inks based on the AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT ensembles under UV (365 nm) or natural light: a) AmC5A/1,8-ANS, 100 × 10−6/100 × 10−6 m; b) AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT, 100 × 10−6/100 × 10−6/4 × 10−6 m; c) AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT, 100 × 10−6/100 × 10−6/10 × 10−6 m; d) AmC5A/DBT, 100 × 10−6/4 × 10−6 m; e) 1,8-ANS, 100 × 10−6 m; f) 1,8-ANS/DBT, 100 × 10−6/4 × 10−6 m; g) AmC5A/1,8-ANS/DBT, 100 × 10−6/100 × 10−6/4 × 10−6 m (natural light); h) Rewriting “N” with AmC5A (100 × 10−6 m) and “K” with AmC5A/DBT (100 × 10−6/10 × 10−6 m) on the preexisting 1,8-ANS ink. It is noted that 1,8-ANS shows no fluorescence in the solution (Figure S21, Supporting Information) but pronounced fluorescence in the solid state. It is reasonably acceptable that the intramolecular rotation was restricted when 1,8-ANS was transferred from the aqueous solution to the solid state.

Wasielewski, J. F. Stoddart, O. A. Scherman, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2015, 137, 15299; e) J. Voskuhl, U. Kauscher, M. Gruener, H. Frisch, B. Wibbeling, C. A. Strassert, B. J. Ravoo, Soft Matter 2013, 9, 2453. [16] a) H.-Q. Peng, L.-Y. Niu, Y.-Z. Chen, L.-Z. Wu, C.-H. Tung, Q.-Z. Yang, Chem. Rev. 2015, 115, 7502; b) A. Reisch, P. Didier, L. Richert, S. Oncul, Y. Arntz, Y. Mély, A. S. Klymchenko, Nat. Commun. 2014, 5, 4089. [17] H. Li, J. Hao, Z. Wu, J. Phys. Chem. B 2008, 112, 3705. [18] a) P.-Z. Chen, Y.-X. Weng, L.-Y. Niu, Y.-Z. Chen, L.-Z. Wu,
C.-H. Tung, Q.-Z. Yang, Angew. Chem. 2016, 128, 2809; b) P.-Z. Chen, Y.-X. Weng, L.-Y. Niu, Y.-Z. Chen, L.-Z. Wu, C.-H. Tung, Q.-Z. Yang, Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 2759. [19] a) Y. Lin, X. Han, X. Cheng, J. Huang, D. Liang, C. Yu, Langmuir 2008, 24, 13918; b) W. Guan, W. Zhou, C. Lu, B. Z. Tang, Angew. Chem. 2015, 127, 15375; c) W. Guan, W. Zhou, C. Lu, B. Z. Tang, Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2015, 54, 15160. [20] The Förster radius (R0), defined as the theoretical donor–acceptor distance at the 50% energy-transfer efficiency, was estimated as 2.8 nm for 1,8-ANS–DBT and 1.2 nm for 1,8-ANS–1,8-ANS (see the Supporting Information). According to the thickness of bilayer (5.1 nm), the averaged distance between donor and acceptor could be estimated as less than 2 nm. The center-to-center distance between cavities was estimated as about 1 nm (Figure S19, Supporting Information). Thus, the high density of 1,8-ANS on the vesicular surface makes it extremely easy to shuttle energy from 1,8- ANS to 1,8-ANS and ultimately to the DBT acceptor.
Adv. Mater. 2016, DOI: 10.1002/adma.201601719
